channel.title: Is there an end to the universe?
channel.description: Is there an end to the universe? or is the rest of it just an empty void?

My friend says its a void…but who knows?

item.title: Is there an end to the universe?
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“heatrn11, post:118, topic:442588”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=545273.msg4002088#msg4002088 date=1338162401]

If you are going to come with bullshit science theory ideas, why don’t you save some time and just say: “God did it”?

I actually took evidence from our planet and applied it to the mystery of the universe. Praise ah la.

If you were meaning Allah please don’t take the micky. Its very disrespectful.

I had an idea, what if the universe was god. What I mean by this is not the way many religions perceive god but the universe is just woah, its unexplainable how it came about in the very beginning, it gave us all life, it is the decider if we have it, its unbiased and so forth… Not saying I think the universe has a mind or anything but it makes sense.
The idea has been thought of before I know as its a very simple idea but I did think of it myself thats why I’m saying I had an idea(can see people saying its this religion or w.e.).

So we all can conclude that the human brain fears what it doesn’t understand…
[/quote]Well said, hardcore religious people give us good examples of that

I do believe in God though.[/quote]
andd?

Read full topic
item.source: Is there an end to the universe?

item.title: Is there an end to the universe?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

The big bang theory is similar to my theory.

your theory would be a hypothesis, the big bang theory would be a scientific theory

Rodgerwilco:

our universe is limited,but yet expands inside itself because of an outside force.

who says the universe is acted upon by an outside force? how could you possibly test or observe that the universe is acted upon by an outside force?

Rodgerwilco:

My theory believes that dark matter does not exist and this continuous movement is actually an outside force.

then your hypothesis doesn’t account for the fact we can observe dark matter and its effects, and this is the very reason your hypothesis isn’t a theory

Rodgerwilco:

My theory is not made up off the top of my head, I examined a drop of water and inside of that drop of water, under a microscope, I added some different “variables” such as sugar, olive oil and other cooking supplies and watched the universe inside unfold to my manipulation.

oh what a great experiment, how would you propose we test for people adding sugar or olive oil to our universe? well, you do say that dark matter doesn’t exist and instead the effects of dark matter are instead an outside force, how would you test for this explanation? because we can test for dark matter and we can observe it, and basic logic dictates that the simplest explanation that works is usually the correct explanation

Rodgerwilco:

It all relates to the Fibonacci sequence.

please feel free to explain how and we, your peers, will review your explanation

Rodgerwilco:

I actually took evidence from our planet and applied it to the mystery of the universe. Praise ah la.

but your experiment on a drop of water in an open system cannot be applied to our universe which may or may not be an open system

Read full topic
item.source: Is there an end to the universe?

item.title: Is there an end to the universe?
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=Rodgerwilco link=topic=545273.msg4000867#msg4000867 date=1337976201]There is no big bang

if there was no big bang, how come we can observe that the universe is still “banging” according to the big bang theory?[/quote]

I won’t deny the fact that there are reactions in the universe. The big bang theory is similar to my theory. My theory does not mention/include when everything is sucked in and the cycle repeats with another bang. Instead the “universe” as we define it… “the totality of everything that exists.” Like a drop of water… our universe is limited,but yet expands inside itself because of an outside force. If you calculate our universes gravity, everything should collapse in on itself but it doesn’t due to “dark matter”. My theory believes that dark matter does not exist and this continuous movement is actually an outside force.

My theory is not made up off the top of my head, I examined a drop of water and inside of that drop of water, under a microscope, I added some different “variables” such as sugar, olive oil and other cooking supplies and watched the universe inside unfold to my manipulation.

It all relates to the Fibonacci sequence.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there an end to the universe?

item.title: Is there an end to the universe?
item.dc:creator: @Wet_Dreamss Wet Dreamss
item.description:
@Wet_Dreamss wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

Not at all, it may be an assumption… but the theory actually has a legitimate case. Taking information from this world, information as in the correlation and function of entities and using that information at hand to build a hypothesis for something much larger.

I couldn’t agree more. God, finally somebody who doesn’t need physical evidence to conclude something.

You sir, are my new idol.

item.title: Is there an end to the universe?
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Not at all, it may be an assumption… but the theory actually has a legitimate case. Taking information from this world, information as in the correlation and function of entities and using that information at hand to build a hypothesis for something much larger. (the universe debate) If your interested in what I use to support my theory, examine a drop of water.

I also just realized that Einsteins theory of time travel is correct and that time travels at a constant speed no matter the amount of gravity.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there an end to the universe?

item.title: Is there an end to the universe?
item.dc:creator: @Xellium Xellium
item.description:
@Xellium wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

There is no big bang and the universe will not collapse in on itself. The universe is a reflection of itself. Inside the universe, there are galaxies and inside the galaxies… solar systems. UNIverse is a mistake. There is not a single universe, but instead, multiple. Multiple universes do not flow around a giant sun or common object but instead reflect upon one another. (Not parallel) An object in one universe cannot travel to another.

Your whole theory is assumptions. It’s quite unimaginable. You can’t even show some real support to this.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there an end to the universe?

item.title: Is there an end to the universe?
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:99, topic:442588"][quote author=Rodgerwilco link=topic=545273.msg4000867#msg4000867 date=1337976201]
There is no big bang and the universe will not collapse in on itself. The universe is a reflection of itself. Inside the universe, there are galaxies and inside the galaxies… solar systems. UNIverse is a mistake. There is not a single universe, but instead, multiple. Multiple universes do not flow around a giant sun or common object but instead reflect upon one another. (Not parallel) An object in one universe cannot travel to another.
[/quote]
Any kind of evidence of this? or just a damn retarded assumption?[/quote]
A damn retarded statement

You can’t just go around saying things you can’t prove as if they’re facts.

Read full topic

item.title: Is there an end to the universe?
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:96, topic:442588”][quote author=m1lkman link=topic=545273.msg4000639#msg4000639 date=1337939688]
What is visible and what isn’t? Aren’t telescopes becoming increasingly more powerful?
[/quote]

due to how the universe is expanding, there are parts of the universe that will never be visible because the light can never reach us[/quote]
^ this

Light cannot traverse the entire universe, so however long the universe has existed x the speed of light is how much of the visible universe we can see. (d = vt)
